!! //SOURCE!//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|SOURCE]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$6edf&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;68&nbsp;[[>>|SKIP]]


Sets the input source to TIB, BLK, or SCR

```
: source!   ( -- )
    blk @  ?dup
    if
        block  isscr?
        if
            3+ @lin !  lin on  #lin off  ['] source.scr
        else
            drop  ['] source.blk
        then
    else
        ['] source.tib
    then
    (source) ! ;
```
~ something here so that LOAD can restore position on a screen #41


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_sourcestore
    jsr enter
    .word blk
    .word fetch
    .word qdup
    .word qbranch
    .byt <(sourcestore02-*+1)
    .word _block
    .word isscrq
    .word qbranch
    .byt <(sourcestore01-*+1)
    .word threeplus
    .word atlin
    .word store
    .word lin
    .word on
    .word numlin
    .word off
    .word plit
    .word _sourcescr
    .word branch
    .byt <(sourcestore03-*+1)
sourcestore01
    .word drop
    .word plit
    .word _sourceblk
    .word branch
    .byt <(sourcestore03-*+1)
sourcestore02
    .word zero
    .word clit
    .byt DFLTN
    .word cstore
    .word plit
    .word _sourcetib
sourcestore03
    .word psource
    .word store
    .word exit

```







!! //SOURCE.BLK//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr size )

[[<<|SOURCE.TIB]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$6e12&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;9&nbsp;[[>>|REFILL.SCR]]


Target of SOURCE vector when input is from the console.  Leaves
an address and size

```
: source.blk   ( -- addr size )
    block b/buf ;
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_sourceblk
    jsr enter
    .word _block
    .word bperbuf
    .word exit

```







!! //SOURCE.SCR//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr size )

[[<<|EOL?.SCR]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$6ec7&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;21&nbsp;[[>>|SOURCE]]


Target of SOURCE vector when input is from a screen.  Leaves
an address pointing to the beginning of a line and line size 40|80

```
: source.scr   ( -- addr size )
    begin
        eol?.scr
    while
        refill.scr
    repeat
    cas2buf  #lin @ ;
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_sourcescr
    jsr enter
sourcescr01
    .word _eolqscr
    .word qbranch
    .byt <(sourcescr02-*+1)
    .word _refillscr
    .word branch
    .byt <(sourcescr01-*+1)
sourcescr02
    .word cas2buf
    .word numlin
    .word fetch
    .word exit

```







!! //SOURCE.TIB//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr size )

[[<<|']]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$6e07&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;11&nbsp;[[>>|SOURCE.BLK]]


Target of SOURCE vector when input is from the console.  Leaves
an address

```
: source.tib   ( -- addr size )
    tib #tib @ ;
```

_sourcetib

    .word tib
    .word numtib
    .word fetch
    .word exit

```







!! SP!&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|EXECUTE]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$07f8&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;7&nbsp;[[>>|HEX]]


Initializes the data stack pointer to the value in user
variable SP0


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
spstore
    ldx uarea+usersp0-userarea
    dex             ; because it's 1> to make ?stack faster
spstoreo
    jmp next

```







!! SP@&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- sp )

[[<<|DROP]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$09c9&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;5&nbsp;[[>>|C@]]

```
spfetch
    txa
push0a
    ldy #0
    beq pushya

!! SPACE&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|IRQ^]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$12f6&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;9&nbsp;[[>>|SPACES]]

_space
    jsr enter
    .word bl
    .word emit
    .word exit

!! SPACES&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( n -- )

[[<<|SPACE]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$12ff&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;19&nbsp;[[>>|TYPE]]


Emits "n" spaces


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_spaces
    jsr enter
    .word zero
    .word _max
    .word zero
#include "page3.i65"
    .word pqdo
    .byt <(spaces02-*+1)
spaces01
    .word _space
#include "page3.i65"
    .word ploop
    .byt <(spaces01-*+1)
spaces02
    .word exit

```







!! SPAN&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr )

[[<<|>IN]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$074d&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;4&nbsp;[[>>|#TIB]]


The address of a variable containing the count of characters
actually received and stored by the last execution of EXPECT


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
span
    jsr uservar
    .byt userspan-userarea

```







PETTIL uses the stack differently from most Forth systems. I went with a split
data stack on the zero page, with TOS in two consecutive bytes.  This works
pretty well, until it's time to do pointers.  For that, there is a routine
called `locals` which primitives can call to make the next few things on the
stack a little more convenient to access.  There is a 32-byte range of zero page
memory ($00..$1F) where PETTIL and Sweet-16 overlap, and `locals` may fill up
$0A..$15 without causing any trouble.  Keep in mind that locals updates the
data stack pointer, effectively [[NIP]]ping the items it copies.

```
    ldy #6
    jsr locals
```
This will put 2OS, 3OS, and 4OS into N0, N1, and N2, respectively, while
leaving TOS untouched.

<<<
It might be easy to switch FIG-FORTH over to a split stack that stores low-byte/high-byte on the zero page as separate ranges (my approach #2). This would create lots of efficiency improvements: pushing and popping are shorter operations (1 operation instead of two, every time). Also, although this would make it slightly nonstandard for Forth, logical calculations and checks could use a 1-byte value and ignore the "high" byte, speeding/simplifying things further. You could have many other 8-bit operations too, which would speed things up. ANS Forth specifies a minimum of 32 cells of Parameter Stack {64 bytes, easily fitting in zpage} and 24 cells of Return Stack {usually this is the page 1 return stack} (Brad Rodriguez prefers 64 cells of each). (By having the TOS be 2 bytes in zpage, you can still use the TOS easily as a pointer.) (Sadly, pointer accesses are harder this way.)
<<< [[David Wheeler|http://www.dwheeler.com/6502/]]  [[also|http://www.dwheeler.com/6502/a-lang.txt]]







!! //SRCTARG//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- var buffer size char  )

[[<<|VERIFY-BUFFERS]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$183c&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;41&nbsp;[[>>|BLOCK]]


[[BLOCK]] packs from or unpacks to [[VIDRAM]] or [[BLKBUF]], based on [[EDITING?]] and [[SCRPKT?]]

~ horrible name

```
: srctarg   ( -- scr|blk vidram|blkbuf b/scr|b/buf bl|0 )
    editing?
    dup  ?: scr blk
    swap ?: vidram blkbuf
    scrpkt?
    dup  ?: b/scr b/buf
    swap ?: bl 0 ;
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_srctarg
    jsr enter
    .word editingq
    .word dup
    .word pquerycolon
    .word scr
    .word blk
    .word swap
    .word pquerycolon
    .word vidram
    .word _blkbuf
    .word isscrq
    .word dup
    .word pquerycolon
    .word bperscr
    .word bperbuf
    .word swap
    .word pquerycolon
    .word bl
    .word zero
    .word exit

```







!! STA,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|SBC,]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7d77&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;6&nbsp;[[>>|ASL,]]


!!!Assembler instruction

ista
    jsr _domcpu
    .byt $80
    .word $1c6c

asmstackh
    jsr docconst
    .byt <stackh

!! STARTUP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr )

[[<<|SYMTAIL]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0705&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;4&nbsp;[[>>|SA#]]


!!!User variable

the development environment, this is set to [[ABORT]]

startup

!! //STASH-FORTH//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|EMPTY-BUFFERS]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$1740&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;10&nbsp;[[>>|RESTORE-FORTH]]


Subroutine to preserve the data stack pointer, stack, Sweet16 and
other Forth zero page during a BASIC system call



<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
stashforth
    stx n                       ; $ff (z) gets messed up by save!  Use N
    jsr aloha2
    lda #2                      ; set direct mode in CHRGET routine
    sta $78                     ; so we get prompts during i/o
    rts

```







!! STATE&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr )

[[<<|REDEFINED]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$6854&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;4&nbsp;[[>>|CSP]]


!!!User variable
The address of the user variable containing the compilation
state.    A non-zero content indicates compilation is occuring,
but the value itself is system dependent.  A Standard Program
may not modify this variable.


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
state
    jsr uservar
    .byt userstate-userarea

```







!! //STRCOMP//

[[<<|symcomp]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$68d7&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;10&nbsp;[[>>|SYMCOMP16]]


Compares two strings known to be the same length pointed to by
`TOS` and `N0`.

|<br><i>inputs</i>|<|
|<b>TOS</b>|NFA|
|<b>N0</b>|NFA being sought|
|<b>Y</b>|length|
|<br><i>returns</i>|<|
|<b>TOS</b>|unchanged|
|<b>N0</b>|unchanged|
|^<b>Y</b>|index of mismatch<br><b>0</b> if success|
|<b>Z</b>|strings match?|
|<b>C</b>|unchanged|


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
strcomp
    lda (tos),y
    eor (n),y
    bne strcomp02
    dey
    bne strcomp
strcomp02
    rts

```







!! STX,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|ROR,]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7da1&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;6&nbsp;[[>>|CPX,]]


!!!Assembler instruction
compiles a STX opcode


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
istx
    jsr _domcpu
    .byt $81
    .word $0414

```







!! STY,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|LDY,]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7dbf&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;6&nbsp;[[>>|JSR,]]


!!!Assembler instruction
compiles a STY opcode


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
isty
    jsr _domcpu
    .byt $80
    .word $048c

```







!! //subeq//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( n1 n2 -- n1 n2 ; returns Z flag )

[[<<|=]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0d27&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;27&nbsp;[[>>|U<]]


Alternate entry point to [[=]] primitive

* Compares the TOS with 2OS
* returns the Z flag
* doesn't alter the stack



<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
subeq
    ;sec                    ; Caller must SEC prior to calling here
    ldy #0
ne01
    lda tos
    eor stackl,x
    sta n
    lda tos+1
    eor stackh,x
    ora n
    bcs subeq99             ; return when called as a subroutine
    bne cmpout02
cmpout01
    tya
    eor #$ff
    tay
cmpout02
    tya
    inx
    jmp put

```







!! SWAP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( n1 n2 -- n2 n1 )

[[<<|OVER]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0bea&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;19&nbsp;[[>>|TUCK]]


Exchange the top two values on the stack.


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
swap
    ldy tos+1
    lda stackh,x
    sta tos+1
    sty stackh,x
    ldy tos
    lda stackl,x
    sta tos
    sty stackl,x
    jmp next

```







This is how to utilize the
[[native 6502 extensions|http://pettil.tumblr.com/post/81057827224/flexible-native-6502-extensions-for-sweet16]]
available in PETTIL.  EXT is a new Sweet-16 instruction, and the subroutine
it hooks to should probably have a register contract between the caller and the
extension.  R11 is used for transferring control to the extension, and R11 is 
also a good candidate for a return argument.

Here's how adding an extension might look in the Forth assembler...

```
CODE DIGITFLIP
    .N0  STA,
    .A   LSR,  .A   LSR,
    .A   LSR,  .A   LSR,
    .N0  ASL,  .N0  ASL,      
    .N0  ASL,  .N0  ASL,      
    .N0  ORA,  ( REVERSE HEXDIGITS )
         RTS,
END-CODE

CODE BACKWARD
    .R11 LDA,
         PHA,
    .R11 1+ LDA,
    DIGITFLIP JSR,
    .R11 STA,
         PLA,
    DIGITFLIP JSR,
    .R11 1+ STA,
         RTS,
END-CODE

CODE TRIVIAL
         BRK,
         PULL,
    .ACC SET,
    6502 ,
    .TOS ADD,
    BACKWARD EXT,
    .R11 LD,
         PUSH,
         NXT,
END-CODE
```
The new Sweet-16 instructions PUSH, PULL, EXT, and NXT, are all in this
example.  Native code extensions typically end with an RTS instruction, to
return control to the Sweet-16 opcode dispatcher.







!! //Sweet16 toggle//

[[<<|Aloha]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0789&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;17&nbsp;[[>>|IRQ toggle]]


Toggle the BRK vector between Sweet16 <--> TIM



<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
togglesw16
    ldy #2
togglesw16a
    lda brktoggle-1,y
    eor CBINV-1,y
    sta CBINV-1,y
    dey
    bne togglesw16a
    rts

brktoggle
    .word SW16^TIMBRK

```







!! //symcomp//

[[<<|NFA+]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$68c3&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;20&nbsp;[[>>|STRCOMP]]


Compares two symbols at TOS and N0

|<br><i>inputs</i>|<|
|<b>TOS</b>|NFA|
|<b>N0</b>|NFA being sought|
|<br><i>returns</i>|<|
|^<b>Y</b>|index of mismatch<br/><b>0</b> if success<br/><b>FF</b> end of list|
|^<b>Z</b>|symbols match?|


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
symcomp
    ldy #0
    lda (tos),y
    bne symcomp01
    dey
    rts
symcomp01
    eor (n),y
    and #$df
    bne strcomp02           ; length, vocab bit or smudge?
    jsr nfalen01
    adc #0
    ;clc
    tay
    ; fall through
```







!! //SYMCOMP16//

[[<<|STRCOMP]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$68e1&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;10&nbsp;[[>>|SYMCOPY16]]


Compares two symbols, returns Sweet-16 Carry flag set if match


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
symcomp16
    jsr symcomp
    clc
    bne symcomp16b
    sec
symcomp16b
    rol R14H
    rts

```







!! //SYMCOPY16//

[[<<|SYMCOMP16]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$68eb&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;28&nbsp;[[>>|PEARSON#]]


Copies a string from (tos) to (n0) via the Y register.
Copies the 0th byte, and moves N0 beyond the copied string

|<br><i>inputs</i>|<|
|<b>TOS</b>|Source base address|
|<b>N0</b>|Target base address|
|<b>Y</b>|Name length (<i>symcopy16a</i>)|
|<br><i>returns</i>|<|
|<b>TOS</b>|unchanged|
|<b>N0</b>|unchanged|
|^<b>Y</b>|<b>FF</b>|
|<b>Z</b>|<b>0</b>|


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
symcopy16
    ldy n+13
    bit n+12
    bvc symcopy16a
    iny
    sty n+13
symcopy16a
    lda (tos),y
    sta (n),y
    dey
    bpl symcopy16a
    sec
    lda n+13
    adc n
    sta n
    bcc symcopy16b
    inc n+1
symcopy16b
    rts

```







!! SYMNEW&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr )

[[<<|FENCE]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$6844&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;4&nbsp;[[>>|#VOC]]


!!!User variable
Start of new (unhashed) symbols. These are [[searched|Search Order]]
first, regardless of length


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
symnew
    jsr uservar
    .byt usersymnew-userarea

```







!! SYMTAB&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr)

[[<<|MEMSIZ]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$06fd&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;4&nbsp;[[>>|SYMTAIL]]


!!!User variable
The symbol table design is one of the most un-Forthy things about PETTIL, or
maybe it's one of the most-Forthy things.  Depends on your perspective.  It's
very nonstandard, I'll grant you that.  But it accomplishes much with a small
code footprint.  Some people would say that Forth is whatever can run a standard
Forth program.  I would say the definition of Forth is closer to "whatever
Chuck Moore wants it to do."  Or in this case what I want it to do.

* Very fast [[FIND]] (and compile) times
* Searches (on average) only 1/16th of the dictionary
* Uses a Bloom filter to weed out numbers
* Disappears completely once the application is built

Symbol table start address, points to a structure in memory
consisting of

|!Field|!Size|!Description|
|Thread addresses|32 bytes|16 pointers to the start of each symbol thread,<br>balanced by a Pearson hash|
|^Thread<br>(repeats 16x)|^2 bytes<br>1 byte<br>1..31&nbsp;bytes<br>(repeats for each<br>symbol in the<br>thread)|^Code field address<br>Length and flags, sorted by ascending length<br>Symbol text|
|>|>|New symbols are appended, unsorted, after the 16th thread<br>See [[SYMNEW]] and [[SYMTAIL]] |
|^Symbols|^2 bytes<br>1 byte<br>1..31 bytes|Code field address<br>Length and flags<br>Symbol text|

The symbol table will vary in size, and as words are added to [[SYMNEW]],
searches will slow down. The word [[REHASH]] rebuilds the symbol table and
empties out [[SYMNEW]].  The symbol table is easily moved as there are no
link fields in PETTIL.`SYMTAB` may be repositioned during [[REHASH]] by
[[AUTOMEM]], which starts it at a page boundary a minimum of two pages
lower than [[BLKBUF]]

* whenever [[FORGET]] is invoked
* whenever the user types [[REHASH]]

!!!pronounced: "sim-tab"


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
symtab
    jsr uservar
    .byt usersymtab-userarea

```







!! SYMTAIL&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr )

[[<<|SYMTAB]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0701&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;4&nbsp;[[>>|STARTUP]]


[heading]User variable[/heading]
Symbol table end address

Where new symbols are appended


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
symtail
    jsr uservar
    .byt usersymtail-userarea

```







!! //SYSERR//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|?STACK]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0834&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;13&nbsp;[[>>|(.")]]


General-purpose error handler, callable from primitives, used
to print a system error message and abort
pass in the error # in Y
      1 stack empty
      2 stack full


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
error
    sty tos
    ldy #0
    sty tos+1
    ldy #<(_fail+3)    ; transfer control to FAIL
    lda #>(_fail+3)
    jmp toforth

```

    .byt $aa

!! TEST&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( )

[[<<|ARGS]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$1a96&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;5&nbsp;[[>>|WARM]]





<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

_test
    jsr enter

```







!! THEN&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( )

[[<<|ELSE]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7488&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;12&nbsp;[[>>|BEGIN]]



```
' ?branch 2 control then ]
    drop ?>resolve ; immediate
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_then
    jsr docontrol
    .word 0
    .byt <(-2)
    .word twodrop
    .word _qtoresolve
    .word exit

```







!! THEN,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|IF,]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7be5&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;35&nbsp;[[>>|ELSE,]]


```
: then,   abs 3 ?pairs here over c@
    if swap ! else over 1+ - swap c! then ; immediate
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_asmthen
    jsr enter
    .word abs
    .word three
;    .word _qpairs
    .word here
    .word over
    .word cfetch
    .word qbranch
    .byt <(asmthen01-*+1)
    .word over
    .word branch
    .byt <(asmthen02-*+1)
asmthen01
    .word over
    .word oneplus
    .word minus
    .word swap
    .word cstore
asmthen02
    .word exit

```







!! THIRD&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( n1 n2 n3 -- n1 n2 n3 n1 )

[[<<|ROT]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0d87&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;7&nbsp;[[>>|3DUP]]






<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
third
    lda stackl+1,x
    ldy stackh+1,x
    jmp pushya

```







!! TIB&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr )

[[<<|CBIT@]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0c91&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;5&nbsp;[[>>|-3]]


The address of the text input buffer.  This buffer is used
to hold characters when the input stream is coming from the
current input device.  The minimum capacity of TIB is 80
characters.

!!!pronounced: "t-i-b"


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
tib
    jsr doconst
    .word BUF       ; $0200

```







* consolidate all compiler page boundary management into one place
* possibly integrate pagemargin with xt,

in a way that doesn't break `?:`


```
#include "page3.i65"
	.word _xtcomma
	.byt $fc
#include "pad.i65"
```






!! TOGGLE&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( addr bitmask -- )

[[<<|+!]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0c4e&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;19&nbsp;[[>>|COUNT]]


Complement the contents of addr by the bit pattern b.


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
toggle
    lda stackl,x
    sta n
    lda stackh,x
    sta n+1
    ldy #0
    lda (n),y
    eor tos
    sta (n),y
    jmp twodrop

```







!! TOS&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- n )

[[<<|N]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7ae9&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;4&nbsp;[[>>|STACKL]]

```
2 cconstant tos
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
asmtos
    jsr docconst
    .byt <tos

```







!! //tos2minus//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( n -- n-2 )

[[<<|locals]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$07c9&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;3&nbsp;[[>>|dectos]]

tos2minus
    jsr dectos                  ; fall through
```

!! TUCK&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( n1 n2 -- n2 n1 n2 )

[[<<|SWAP]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0bfd&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;24&nbsp;[[>>|-ROT]]


Insert the top item on the stack beneath the second.


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
tuck
    dex
    jsr tuckdashrot
    jmp next

tuckdashrot
    lda stackh+1,x
    sta stackh,x
    lda stackl+1,x
    sta stackl,x
    lda tos+1
    sta stackh+1,x
    lda tos
    sta stackl+1,x
    rts

```













!! TXA,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

!! TYPE&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( addr count -- )

[[<<|SPACES]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$1312&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;43&nbsp;[[>>|/STRING]]




<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
type
    ;ldy #2
    jsr locals2
    clc
    lda tos
    adc uarea+usernumout-userarea
    sta uarea+usernumout-userarea
    lda tos+1
    adc uarea+usernumout-userarea+1
    sta uarea+usernumout-userarea+1
    ;ldy #0
type01
    cpy tos
    bne type02
    dec tos+1
    bpl type02
    jmp drop
type02
    lda (n),y
    jsr CHROUT
    iny
    bne type01
    inc n+1
    bne type01

```







!! U.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( n -- )

[[<<|D.]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$14c8&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;8&nbsp;[[>>|.]]





<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_udot
    jsr enter
    .word _pudot
    .word branch
    .byt <(tse-*+1)
```







!! U.R&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( u w -- )

[[<<|.]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$14db&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;10&nbsp;[[>>|.R]]



 u is converted using the value of BASE and then
 displayed as an unsigned number right-aligned
 in a field +n characters wide.  If the number
 of characters required to display u is greater
 than +n, an error condition exists.



<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_udotr
    jsr enter
    .word tor
    .word _pudot
    .word branch
    .byt <(rjustify-*+1)
```







!! U<&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( n1 n2 -- flag )

[[<<|subeq]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0d42&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;7&nbsp;[[>>|<]]






<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
ult
    jsr cmp16
    bcs cmpout02
    bcc cmpout01            ; bra

```







!! UD.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( ud -- )

[[<<|(.)]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$14b8&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;8&nbsp;[[>>|D.]]





<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

_uddot
    jsr enter
    .word _puddot
    .word branch
    .byt <(tse-*+1)
```







!! UD.R&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( d w -- )

[[<<|.R]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$14ef&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;10&nbsp;[[>>|D.R]]





<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_uddotr
    jsr enter
    .word tor
    .word _puddot
    .word branch
    .byt <(rjustify-*+1)
```







!! UD/MOD&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( ud1 u2 -- u3 ud4 )

[[<<|UM*]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0aab&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;67&nbsp;[[>>|UM/MOD]]



http://www.bradrodriguez.com/papers/camel09.txt
\   High level: numeric output                   (c) 31mar95 bjr
: UD/MOD      \ ud1 u2 -- u3 ud4     32/16->32 divide
    >R 0 R@ UM/MOD  ROT ROT R> UM/MOD ROT ;



<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
udslashmod
        stx z         ; saves a dex;dex later
        ;ldy #4
        jsr locals4       ; dividend to n0..n3
        clc
        ;ldy #0           ; locals does this for us
        ldx #33
        tya
        beq udslashmodb   ; bra to initialization code
udslashmoda
        rol n+4           ; [5] I don't know what this 2-bytes is called
        rol n+5           ; [5] trial minuend or something like that
        sec               ; [2]
        lda n+4           ; [3]
        sbc tos           ; [3]
        tay               ; [2]
        lda n+5           ; [3]
        sbc tos+1         ; [3]
        bcc udslashmodc   ; save or abandon the trial subtraction
udslashmodb
        sty n+4           ; [2+3+3] or [3]?
        sta n+5           ; treating this as [~6] clocks on average
udslashmodc
        rol n+0           ; [5]
        rol n+1           ; [5]
        rol n+2           ; [5]
        rol n+3           ; [5]
        dex               ; [2]
        bne udslashmoda   ; [3]
                ; [54] or [59] clocks for 33x main loop = [1839]
        ldx z
        lda n+5
        sta stackh+1,x
        lda n+4
        sta stackl+1,x
        lda n+1
        sta stackh,x
        lda n
        sta stackl,x
        ldy n+3
        lda n+2
        jmp put        ; push quotient(hi) on stack

```







!! UM*&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( u1 u2 -- ud )

[[<<|FAIL]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0a6b&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;64&nbsp;[[>>|UD/MOD]]


"ud" is the unsigned product of "u1" times "u2".  All values and
arithmetic are unsigned.

A proper 6502 assembler solution.

Features

* multiplies two 8-bit numbers with 16 bit result
* inner loop of only 17 clock cycles per iteration
* worst case behaviour of 40 clock cycles per iteration
* minimizes number of iterations
* total execution time 25 - 320 cycles

(i.e. only 3x slower (worst case) than MUL on Intel 8088)

* 43 bytes size
* relocatable to about anywhere in address space
* uses C64-friendly memory locations

 INPUT  = op1 in A, op2 in X

 OUTPUT = low byte in X, high byte in Y

 memory locations used as temp space = $fb, $fc, $fd

```
;You beat me to the punch, but there is some unnecessary code in there (you don't need to clear the carry before a LSR). And trashing X is unnecessary since you can test for zero just as fast with LDA $02. Or with some crazy jujitsu to save a byte...
;Here's my version, handles 8-bit operands:
;--$00 holds operand 1
;--$01 (low byte) and $02 (high byte) hold operand 2
;--$03 (low byte) and $04 (high byte) hold product
;       cld
;Loop
;    lsr $00
;    bcc NoAdd
;    clc
;    lda $03
;    adc $01
;    sta $03
;    lda $04
;    adc $02
;    sta $04
;    .byte $2C
;NoAdd
;    beq Done
;    asl $01
;    rol $02
;    bcc Loop        ;this assumes that operand 2 is 8-bit
;Done
;
;A proper 6502 assembler solution.
;
;Features
;- multiplies two 8-bit numbers with 16 bit result
;- inner loop of only 17 clock cycles per iteration
;- worst case behaviour of 40 clock cycles per iteration
;- minimizes number of iterations
;- total execution time 25 - 320 cycles
;(i.e. only 3x slower (worst case) than MUL on Intel 8088)
;- 43 bytes size
;- relocatable to about anywhere in address space
;- uses C64-friendly memory locations
; INPUT  = op1 in A, op2 in X
; OUTPUT = low byte in X, high byte in Y
; memory locations used as temp space = $fb, $fc, $fd
;    stx $fc    ; save op2
;    cmp $fc    ; compare both operands
;    bcc noswap ; swap them unless op1 < op2
;    sta $fc    ; save op1 instead of op2
;    txa        ; swap op2 for op1
;noswap
;    ldx #$00   ; prepare result low byte
;    stx $fd    ; clear high byte of op2
;    ldy #$00   ; prepare result high byte
;    beq begin  ; skip shift of op2 for first iteration
;loop
;    asl $fc    ; multiply op2 by 2, low byte
;    rol $fd    ; multiply op2 by 2, high byte
;begin
;    lsr        ; divide op1 by 2
;    bcs add    ; if op1 was odd before division, add op2
;    bne loop   ; if op1 is not zero repeat loop
;    rts        ; otherwise return result
;add
;    sta $fb    ; save current value of op1
;    clc        ; prepare addition
;    txa        ; fetch low byte
;    adc $fc    ; add op2, low byte
;    tax        ; store low byte
;    tya        ; fetch high byte
;    adc $fd    ; add op2, high byte
;    tay        ; store high byte
;    lda $fb    ; restore op1
;    bne loop   ; if op1 is not zero repeat loop
;    rts        ; otherwise return result
;

    stx $fc    ; save op2
    cmp $fc    ; compare both operands
    bcc noswap ; swap them unless op1 < op2
    sta $fc    ; save op1 instead of op2
    txa        ; swap op2 for op1
noswap
    ldx #$00   ; prepare result low byte
    stx $fd    ; clear high byte of op2
    ldy #$00   ; prepare result high byte
    beq begin  ; skip shift of op2 for first iteration
loop
    asl $fc    ; multiply op2 by 2, low byte
    rol $fd    ; multiply op2 by 2, high byte
begin
    lsr        ; divide op1 by 2
    bcs add    ; if op1 was odd before division, add op2
    bne loop   ; if op1 is not zero repeat loop
    rts        ; otherwise return result
add
    sta $fb    ; save current value of op1
    clc        ; prepare addition
    txa        ; fetch low byte
    adc $fc    ; add op2, low byte
    tax        ; store low byte
    tya        ; fetch high byte
    adc $fd    ; add op2, high byte
    tay        ; store high byte
    lda $fb    ; restore op1
    bne loop   ; if op1 is not zero repeat loop
    rts        ; otherwise return result

```
check http://6502.org/source/ for multiply and divide and stuff


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
umstar
    lda stackl,x
    sta n+4
    lda stackh,x            ;multiplicand in tos
    sta n+5                 ;multiplier in N2
    jsr multiply            ;16 bit unsigned multiply
    lda n
    sta stackl,x
    lda n+1
    sta stackh,x
    lda n+2
    ldy n+3
    jmp put

multiply
    lda #0                  ; unsigned multiply tos*N2 destroys tos
    sta n+2                 ;clear upper half of product
    sta n+3
    ldy #16
rshift
    lsr tos+1
    ror tos
    bcc rrot                ;Go rotate right if c = 0
    clc                     ; and add multiplicand to
    lda n+2                 ;Get upper half of product
    adc n+4                 ; it
    sta n+2
    lda n+3
    adc n+5
rrot
    ror                     ;shift partial product right
    sta n+3
    ror n+2
    ror n+1
    ror n
    dey                     ;Decrement bit count and
    bne rshift
    rts

```







!! UM/MOD&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( ud u -- rem quot )

[[<<|UD/MOD]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0aee&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;72&nbsp;[[>>|AND]]


Perform an unsigned division of the 16-bit "u" into the double
"ud", leaving the 16-bit unsigned remainder and quotient on
the stack

      http://6502.org/source/integers/ummodfix/ummodfix.htm

!!! pronounced: "u-m slash mod"


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
umslashmod
    lda stackl,x
    cmp tos
    lda stackh,x
    sbc tos+1
    bcs umslashmodx
umslashmoda
    lda #17
    sta n       ; counter
umslashmodb
    rol stackl+1,x
    rol stackh+1,x
    dec n
    beq umslashmodz
    rol stackl,x
    rol stackh,x
    lda #$80
    rol
    sta n+1         ; carry
    ;sec
    lda stackl,x
    sbc tos
    sta n+2
    lda stackh,x
    sbc tos+1
    tay
    lda n+1
    sbc #0
    bcc umslashmodb

    lda n+2
    sta stackl,x
    sty stackh,x
    bcs umslashmodb

umslashmodx
    lda #$ff
    sta stackl,x
    sta stackh,x
    sta stackh+1,x
    sta stackl+1,x
umslashmodz
    jsr slide                   ; ~
    jmp swap

```







!! UNDEFINE&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|XT,]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$70ac&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;27&nbsp;[[>>|?ERROR]]


Removes the most recently defined symbol in SYMNEW.  Used by
error recovery

```
: undefine   ( -- )
    latest 2-  dup symtail !  dup @ dp !  3 erase ;
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_undefine
    jsr enter
    .word _latest
    .word twominus
    .word dup
    .word symtail
    .word store
    .word dup
    .word fetch
    .word dp
    .word store
    .word three
    .word _erase
    .word exit

```







!! UNDER&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( n1 n2 -- n1 n1 n2 )

[[<<|3DUP]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0d9b&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;12&nbsp;[[>>|+UNDER]]



 Make a duplicate of the second stack element beneath `TOS`



<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
under
    dex
    lda stackh+1,x
    sta stackh,x
    lda stackl+1,x
    sta stackl,x
    jmp next

```







!! //UNLOOP//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|(LOOP)]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$08da&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;9&nbsp;[[>>|EXIT]]


Exits from a [[DO]]-[[LOOP]], either because the index exceeded the limit, or
early exit due to [[LEAVE]] or [[?LEAVE]]


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
unloop
    ldy #$fc
unloop01
    pla
    sta zi-$fc,y  ; effective address wraps around
    iny
    bne unloop01
    ;fall through
```







!! UNSMUDGE&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( nfa -- )

[[<<|BLOOMHASH01]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$696e&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;2&nbsp;[[>>|SMUDGE]]


Turn off the smudge bit so it can be found by [[FIND]].  In
PETTIL, the smudge bit does double duty, also deactivating any
words that have been [[REDEFINED]].

```
symbol table entry
+---------------+
|   CFA[low]    |  -2      Code field address
|   CFA[high]   |
+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
[S]             |  NFA     Smudge bit
| [V]           |          Vocabulary bit
|   [I]         |          Immediate bit
|     [   len   ]          Length field
+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
|   name[1]     |  +1      Name field
|           ... |
|   name[len]   |  +len
+---------------+
?   vocabid     ?  +len+1  Vocabulary token (if Vocab bit set)
+---------------+
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
unsmudge
    clc
    .byt $29            ; AND #
    ; fall through
```







!! //UNSMUDGECLONE16//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( nfa -- nfa )

[[<<|QSMUDGE]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$6982&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;3&nbsp;[[>>|SMUDGECLONE16]]


Unsmudge the last clone


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
unsmudgeclone16
    clc
    bcc qsmudge            ; bra

```







!! UNTIL&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( )

[[<<|WHILE]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$74ae&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;12&nbsp;[[>>|AGAIN]]



```
' ?branch -1 control until
    ] q<resolve drop ;
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_until
    jsr docontrol
    .word qbranch
    .byt <(-1)
    .word _qfromresolve
    .word drop
    .word exit

```







!! UNTIL,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|BEGIN,]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7bc1&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;21&nbsp;[[>>|IF,]]


```
: until,   >r 1 ?pairs r> c, here 1+ - c, ; immediate
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_asmuntil
    jsr enter
    .word tor
    .word one
;    .word _qpairs
    .word rfrom
    .word _ccomma
    .word here
    .word oneplus
    .word minus
    .word _ccomma
    .word exit

```







!! UP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- n )

[[<<|Z]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7add&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;4&nbsp;[[>>|IP]]


!!!Assembler constant
User pointer, points to the user variable area

```
84 cconstant up
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
asmup
    jsr docconst
    .byt <up

```







!! UPDATE&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|(UPD3)]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$191d&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;86&nbsp;[[>>|MSB]]


Copies and compresses the current block buffer to the [[virtual memory
packet buffer|PETTIL system memory map]].  Analogous to [[BLOCK]] which
reads packets, this is PETTIL's single point of responsibility for
writing packets in the [[VMBUF]] region.

```
: update   ( -- )
    #vmpkt @ 0= ?exit                   \ early exit if buffer empty
    blkbuf  editing? if
        drop  isscr? ?: vidram exit     \ early exit if editing data
    then
    vmbuf b/buf
    b/buf blk  isscr? if
        2drop  b/scr scr
    then
    @ >pkt
    (upd1)
    cmove
    25 wrap^ scrpkt
    (upd2)
    ?: -trailing -nulls  nip rlencode isscr?
    (upd3)
    +move #vmpkt! ;
```
d;m 0;m 1f0 1ff;m 4ed0 4eff;m 52c0 532f;z


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_update
    jsr enter
    .word numvmpkt
    .word fetch
    .word zeq
    .word _qexit
    .word _blkbuf
    .word editingq
    .word qbranch
    .byt <(update01-*+1)
    .word drop
    .word isscrq
    .word pquerycolon
    .word vidram
    .word exit
update01
    .word vmbuf
    .word bperbuf
    .word bperbuf
    .word blk
    .word isscrq
    .word qbranch
    .byt <(update02-*+1)
    .word twodrop
    .word bperscr
    .word scr
update02
    .word fetch
    .word _topkt
    .word _pktsize
    .word pupd1
    .word cmove
    .word clit
    .byt 25
    .word wrapabove
    .word scrpkt
    .word pupd2
    .word pquerycolon
    .word dashtrailing
    .word dashnulls
    .word nip
    .word rlencode
    .word isscrq
    .word pupd3
    .word _plusmove
    .word _numvmpktstore
    .word exit
```







!! USER&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( n -- )

[[<<|LAUNCH]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$6829&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;8&nbsp;[[>>|+ORIGIN]]


A defining word used in the form:

`n USER cccc`

which creates a user variable cccc.
The parameter field of cccc contains n as a fixed offset relative to
the user pointer register UP for this user variable. When cccc is
later executed, it places the sum of its offset and the user area
base address on the stack as the storage address of that
particular variable.



<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
user
    jsr enter
    .word _constant
   ;~ .word _psemi
    jmp uservar

```







!! //User Area//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|Zero page buffer and NEXT routine]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$065c&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;122&nbsp;[[>>|Core includes]]


Storage for user variables and initialization data for some of them


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
userarea
; uarea initialization data
; WARM
userup          .word uarea     ;
usersp0         .word bos+1     ;
userrp0         .word $01fe     ;
userwarm

; COLD
userfence       .word cold      ;
userdp          .word cold      ;
userstartup     .word _hot      ;
usermemsiz      .word 0         ; calculated at startup
                                ; keep the next three uservars together
userfilename    .word currname  ; counted string, default filename
                                ; is "PETTILPACKETS"
usersanum       .word 0         ; secondary address is 0, (PRG file)
userdrvnum      .word 1         ; cassette #1 is default device
usercold

; SOFT
; everything below initializes to 0 at COLD and is untouched by WARM
;
; memory pointers, in descending order
usercurrent     = usercold+0
usernewdp       = usercold+2    ; // FORGET relies on NEWDP immediately
usertdict       = usercold+4    ; \\ preceding TDICT in uarea
usertdp         = usercold+6
usersymtab      = usercold+8
usersymnew      = usercold+10
usersymtail     = usercold+12
uservmbuf       = usercold+14
usernumvmpkt    = usercold+16
userblk         = usercold+18
userscr         = usercold+20
userlin         = usercold+22
useratlin       = usercold+24
usernumlin      = usercold+26
userscrpkt      = usercold+28
userediting     = usercold+30
usernumvoc      = usercold+32
usernewest      = usercold+34
userredefined   = usercold+36
userwarning     = usercold+38
userbase        = usercold+40
userdpl         = usercold+42
userhld         = usercold+44
usertoin        = usercold+46
userspan        = usercold+48
usernumtib      = usercold+50
usernumout      = usercold+52
usernumline     = usercold+54
userstate       = usercold+56
usercsp         = usercold+58
uservsource     = usercold+60

; User Pointer (UP) at $0002 points here
uarea           .dsb usercold-userarea+80,0

    ; test page-alignment, remove from release
    .byt ""

; xor of two vectors, to switch IRQ vector between PETTIL and BASIC
irqtoggle       .word 0

```







!! //USERVAR//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr )

[[<<|Core includes]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$06d6&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;23&nbsp;[[>>|SP0]]


Runtime action of all user variables.  Returns the address of
the user variable.

NOTE: no page-boundary crossing in user variable space [[UAREA]]


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
uservar
    ldy #1
    clc
    .byt $29            ; AND # instruction
struct
    sec
    pla
    sta n
    pla
    sta n+1
    lda (n),y
    bcc uservar01
    rts                 ; return from `jsr struct` call
uservar01
    adc up
    ldy up+1
;    bcc uservar02       ; not needed -- user area limited to same page
;    iny
;uservar02
    jmp pushya

```







!! VARIABLE&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|2CONSTANT]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$71e8&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;11&nbsp;[[>>|LATEST]]


A defining word executed in the form:
       `VARIABLE <name>`
A dictionary entry for <name> is created and two bytes are
ALLOTted in its parameter field.  This parameter field is to
be used for contents of the variable.  The application is
responsible for initializing the contents of the variable
which it creates.  When <name> is later executed, the
address of its parameter field is placed on the stack.


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_variable
    jsr enter
    .word _create
    .word two
    .word _allot
    .word exit

```







!! VDROP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|(VOCAB)]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7314&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;16&nbsp;[[>>|2VARIABLE]]


Remove the first vocabulary from [[VSTACK]].

```
: vdrop   ( -- )
    current @ context ! ?csp latest unsmudge ;
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_vdrop
    jsr enter
    .word vstack
    .word oneplus
    .word vstack
    .word clit
    .byt 9
    .word cmove
    .word exit

```







!! VERIFY-BUFFERS&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|LOAD-BUFFERS]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$1823&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;25&nbsp;[[>>|SRCTARG]]


Verifies the [[VMBUF]] area following a write

called by STOP-V in the editor

```
: verify-buffers   ( -- )
    1 (loadverify)
    ST c@  if  ." error"  then ;
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_verifybuffers
    jsr enter
    .word one               ; VERIFY
    .word _ploadverify
    .word clit
    .byt STATUS
    .word cfetch
    .word qbranch
    .byt <(verifybuffers05-*+1)
    .word pdq
    .byt (verifybuffers06-*-1)
    .asc "ERROR"
verifybuffers06
verifybuffers05
    .word exit

```







!! VIDRAM&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- $8000 )

[[<<|LSB]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$1981&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;5&nbsp;[[>>|MON]]


Constant, address of PET video memory $8000


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
vidram
    jsr doconst
    .word VIDRAM

```







!!Virtual Memory

!!!General
There is a single 1K block buffer (yes. just one buffer. yes. I know.) located directly below the [[symbol table|SYMTAB]].  Blocks are rlencoded and stored in the virtual memory buffer ([[VMBUF]]).  This `VMBUF` area is saved, loaded and verified in its entirety as a PRG file.  This could be to tape or disk, but currently only tape is supported, as that's what most of us had.  

!!!Packets
The packeting scheme handles two types of block, using metadata to distinguish them.  This approach came about to support the 1000-byte character limit of the display and the PET native editor's linewrapping features for source code while still providing traditional 1024-byte Forth blocks.  Each packet consists of a two-byte header

|f|e|d|c|b|a|9|8|7|6|5|4|3|2|1|0||h
|^S||^-|^-|^-||<|<|<|<|<|<|<|<|<|<|packet type<br/>0=data packet<br/>1=screen packet|
||^C|^-|^-|^-||<|<|<|<|<|<|<|<|<|<|compression flag<br/>0=compressed<br/>1=uncompressed|
||<|^-|^-|^-|^L|^L|^L|^L|^L|^L|^L|^L|^L|^L|^L|packet length<br/>(including header)|

!!!Data vs. Screen packets
|^Data|^Screen|h
|^1024 bytes|^1003 bytes<br/>3 linewrap<br/>1000 screen codes|
|^read-only in editor|^editable in editor|
|^initialized to zeroes<br/>[[ERASE]]|^initialized to spaces<br/>[[BLANK]]|
|^msb of header [[OFF]]<br/>(AND $7FFF)|^msb of header [[ON]]<br/>(OR $8000)|
|^always unpacks to [[BLKBUF]]|^unpacks to [[VIDRAM]] (only when [[EDITING?]])|

!!!Relocation

When the Transient dictionary and symbols aren't present, the [[block buffer|BLKBUF]] will be 1K below the top of physical memory. Saving to disk or tape adjusts the start and end pointers in the tape header to always end at this address, and loading or verifying will adjust the start and end address to reflect the current location of [[VMBUF]]

!!!Creating blocks
The packet number is implicit by that packet's position within VMBUF.  The packet header stored at BUFFER-2 is for packet 0, and packets build downward from there.  BLOCK can't refer to a packet that doesn't exist, so when a packet is referenced by BLOCK, new packets may need to be created.  If EDITING? is false, all newly created blocks will be data packets, otherwise they will be screen packets

!!!Virtual memory words
*[[BUFFER]]  ( u -- addr )<br>Returns the //addr// of [[BLKBUF]] and sets either [[SCR]] or [[BLK]] = //u//.  No packet is created in the [[VMBUF]] region until [[UPDATE]], and no initialization of the [[BLKBUF]] buffer contents occurs.
*[[BLKBUF]]  ( -- addr )<br>Returns the //addr// of BLKBUF.  No packet is registered to the buffer.
*[[UPDATE]]   ( -- )<br>commits the current PACKET to the VMBUF
*[[BLOCK]]   ( u -- addr )<br>Unpacks the requested block from VMBUF to BUFFER, creating it and any lower-numbered blocks if necessary.  BUFFER is first filled with spaces.
*[[RLENCODE]]   ( source dest srcsize -- finaldest flag )<br>Performs a run-length encoding operation on the region of memory between //source// and (//source//+//srcsize//) with the output delivered to //dest//.  The //finaldest// returned is the next available address following the compressed data, and //flag// indicates if RLENCODE was unable (//flag//=true) to compress the data smaller than it    s original size, and was simply copied.  Compressed data returns //flag//=false.
*[[RLDECODE]]   ( source dest srcsize -- finaldest )<br>Uncompresses //srcsize// bytes of data beginning at //source//, delivering the output at //dest//.
*[[VMBUF]]   ( -- addr )<br>User Variable<br>The bottom address of the virtual memory buffer.  The buffer grows downward, and is always marked by a zero-word at the tail.
*[[#VMPKT]]  ( -- addr )<br>User Variable<br>The current number of packets in VMBUF.  EMPTY-BUFFERS resets this to zero.
*[[SCR]]   ( -- addr )<br>User Variable<br>Current screen.  The screen most recently edited or listed.  SCR might hold the block number of a data packet, but the editor views data packets in read-only mode.  Writable screen packets are commited to the VMBUF (by UPDATE) when the user navigates away from the screen in the editor or [[exits|STOP-Q]] the editor.
*[[EDITING]]   ( -- addr )<br>User Variable, determines whether system is in screen editor mode<br>
*[[EDITING?]]   ( -- flag )<br>Retrieves [[EDITING]] value<br>
*[[VIDRAM]]   ( -- $8000 )<br>Constant<br>The address of the upper left corner of the screen, the start of the memory-mapped video area
*[[SAVE-BUFFERS]]   ( -- )<br>Writes the memory between [[VMBUF]] and [[BLKBUF]] out to tape via the kernel SAVE routine.
*[[LOAD-BUFFERS]]   ( -- )<br>Searches on the DRV# device for the named file stored in FILENAME and reads it in at PAD, initially.   After LOAD completes, the memory will be moved to just below BUFFER, then VMBUF and #PKTS will be set to reflect what was loaded.  If FILENAME is off, or the length is zero, LOAD-BUFFERS will read the next file. 
*[[EMPTY-BUFFERS]]   ( -- )<br>Empties the virtual memory packet buffer by setting VMBUF to BUFFER-2 and storing a zero there, and resets #PKTS to zero.
*[[FLUSH]]   ( -- )<br>performs [[SAVE-BUFFERS]] then [[EMPTY-BUFFERS]]
*[[FILENAME]]   ( -- addr )<br>User Variable<br>The address of a counted string.  The first 16 characters is the filename for [[SAVE-BUFFERS]] or [[LOAD-BUFFERS]]
*[[DRV#]]   ( -- addr )<br>User Variable<br>Contains the current device number for [[SAVE-BUFFERS]] and [[LOAD-BUFFERS]].  The default value is 1 (cassette #1)







!! VMBUF&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr )

[[<<|FILENAME]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0715&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;4&nbsp;[[>>|#VMPKT]]


!!!User variable
User variable that points to the bottom of the virtual memory
packet buffer.  Save and Verify operations use this as their
base address.  Load operations will load from magnetic media
to [[PAD]], then [[move|MOVE]] that data up so it ends just below
[[BLKBUF]] before setting `VMBUF`.  Creating and destroying
packets changes the value of `VMBUF`

!!!pronounced: "v-m-buff"


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
vmbuf
    jsr uservar
    .byt uservmbuf-userarea

```







!!!Words
Vocabularies are created by the defining word [[VOCABULARY]] followed 
by the name of the new vocabulary.  Vocabularies are identified in
PETTIL by a numeric identifier.  `0` is the id for [[FORTH]] and
`1` is the [[ASSEMBLER]] vocabulary id.

[[DEFINITIONS]] changes the compilation vocabulary [[CURRENT]] to 
the first vocabulary in the search order.

[[FORTH]] is the root vocabulary and is always searched last.

!!!Search Order
There is a vocabulary stack [[VSTACK]] with a maximum capacity of 10 
vocabularies.  Vocabularies are added to the front of this list by
executing the vocabulary word as it was defined by [[VOCABULARY]]
The search order proceeds from the most recently invoked to the least
recent, and the root [[FORTH]] vocabulary is always searched last.
FORTH is the only vocabulary searched at system startup.

!!!Resetting the Vocabulary Stack
* Invoking [[FORTH]] resets the vocabulary stack.  The compilation
vocabulary [[CURRENT]] is unaffected. 
* Invoking [[VOCABULARY]] creates a new vocabulary in the root without
affecting the search order [[VSTACK]] or the compilation vocabulary
[[CURRENT]]
* [[ABORT]] (any error, or system startup) resets both the search 
order [[VSTACK]] and compilation vocabulary [[CURRENT]] to [[FORTH]]

!!!Flat model
Vocabularies in PETTIL do not nest within each other.  All vocabularies
are siblings of the root vocabulary, and are searched in the reverse
order they were invoked may not be nested within other vocabularies.  

!!!Example
```
VOCABULARY LATIN
LATIN DEFINITIONS
: EPLURIBUSUNUM ;
: CAVEATEMPTOR ;
VOCABULARY PIGLATIN
PIGLATIN
: CARPEDIEM ;  ( added to LATIN )
DEFINITIONS
: IXNAY ;  ( added to PIGLATIN )
EPLURIBUSUNUM  OK
IXNAY  OK
DEPTH . 0  OK
FORTH PIGLATIN  OK
IXNAY  OK
EPLURIBUSUNUM  NOT FOUND
IXNAY  NOT FOUND  ( search order is reset by error )
```







!! VOCABULARY&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( "name" -- )

[[<<|IMMEDIATE]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$72a9&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;52&nbsp;[[>>|DEDUPVOCAB]]


PETTIL vocabularies are flat

see [[FD-V05N3 p. 5|http://www.forth.org/fd/FD-V05N3.pdf]]

```
: vocabulary   ( "name" -- )
    current dup @ over 2>r off
    ['] dovocab  (create)  #voc dup 1+! @ c,
    latest c@ $1f and swap c!
    2r> ! ;
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_vocabulary
    jsr enter
    .word current
    .word dup
    .word fetch
    .word over
    .word twotor
    .word off
    .word plit
    .word dovocab
    .word _pcreate
    .word numvoc
    .word dup
    .word oneplusstore
    .word fetch
    .word _ccomma
    .word _latest
    .word dup
    .word cfetch
    .word clit
    .byt $1f
    .word andx
    .word swap
    .word cstore
    .word tworfrom
    .word store
    .word exit

```







!! VS&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|>=]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7c6f&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;4&nbsp;[[>>|CODE-SETUP]]


```
50 cconstant vs ( assembler test for overflow set )
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
asmvs
    jsr docconst
    .byt $50

```







!! VSTACK&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr )

[[<<|>SYMS]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$6875&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;13&nbsp;[[>>|FORTH]]


Vocabulary stack establishes search order.  [[FORTH]] (vocid = 0) is
the last vocabulary searched, and is always present.  Executing a
vocabulary pushes it to the head of this stack.


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
vstack
    jsr docreate
    .dsb 10,0

```







!! //WARM//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|TEST]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$1a9b&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;75&nbsp;[[>>|COLD]]


Dropping out to BASIC can be accomplished on purpose with MON
(to get to TIM), then .X to get to BASIC.  It also will happen
by mistake if cassette i/o is interrupted by the STOP key or
any tape error.  There may be other ways.  WARM should be able
to bring the system back to a usable state.

!!Tasks

* aloha
* - swap zero page with zpbuf
* - switch Sweet16<-->TIM BRK vector
* - switch PETTIL<-->BASIC IRQ vector
* reset Forth return stack (machine stack)
* reset Forth data stack
* print start message CR,"WELCOME TO PETTIL!",CR
* STARTUP @ EXECUTE


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
warm
    ldy #userwarm-userarea-1    ; init only warm uservariables
    bne warm01
cold2warm
    ldy #usercold-userarea-1    ; init both cold and warm uservariables
warm01
    tya                         ; Y is # of bytes of userarea to move
    pha
    jsr aloha                   ; swap zero page, enable Sweet16, set IRQ
    pla
    tay
    lda userup                  ; initialize user variables
    sta up
    lda userup+1
    sta up+1
warm02
    lda userarea,y
    sta (up),y
    dey
    bpl warm02
    ldy #<(warm03)
    lda #>(warm03)              ; load Y last to clear Z flag
    jmp toforth
warm03
    .word rpstore           ; and we're off
    .word spstore
    .word decimal
    .word pdq
    .byt (warm04-*-1)
    .asc    CR,"WELCOME TO PETTIL!",CR
warm04
    .word startup
    .word fetch
    .word execute
    .word exit

;==============================================================
; FENCE  all that comes before this is unforgettable

```







!! WARNING&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr )

[[<<|#LINE]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$075d&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;4&nbsp;[[>>|slide]]


User variable
A user variable containing a value controlling messages.

* 0 = messages will be presented by number
* addr = address of the error messages table


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
warning
    jsr uservar
    .byt userwarning-userarea
```







!! WHILE&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( )

[[<<|BEGIN]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$74a2&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;12&nbsp;[[>>|UNTIL]]



```
' ?branch -1 control while
    ] +/-pairs ?>mark ; immediate
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_while
    jsr docontrol
    .word qbranch
    .byt <(-1)
    .word plusminuspairs
    .word _qtomark
    .word exit

```







!! WHILE,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|AGAIN,]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7c30&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;19&nbsp;[[>>|REPEAT,]]


```
: while,   >r dup 1 ?pairs r> [compile] if, 2+ ; immediate
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_asmwhile
    jsr enter
    .word tor
    .word dup
    .word one
;    .word _qpairs
    .word rfrom
    .word _compile
    .word _asmif
    .word twoplus
    .word exit

```







!! WORD&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( char -- addr )

[[<<|'STREAM]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$6f58&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;55&nbsp;[[>>|?CHAR]]


 Generates a counted string by non-destructively accepting
 characters from the input stream until the delimiting
 character char is encountered or the input stream is
 exhausted.  Leading delimiters are ignored.  The entire
 character string is stored in memory beginning at addr as a
 sequence of bytes.  The string is followed by a blank which
 is not included in the count.  The first byte of the string
 is the number of characters {0..255}.  If the string is
 longer than 255 characters, the count is unspecified.  If
 the input stream is already exhausted as WORD is called,
 then a zero length character string will result.

 If the delimiter is not found the value of >IN is the size
 of the input stream.  If the delimiter is found >IN is
 adjusted to indicate the offset to the character following
 the delimiter.  #TIB is unmodified.

 The counted string returned by WORD may reside in the "free"
 dictionary area at HERE or above.  Note that the text
 interpreter may also use this area.
See: http://forth.sourceforge.net/std/fst83/fst83-5.htm#input.stream

```
: word   ( char -- addr )
    >r 'stream
    under r@ skip  under r> scan  drop
    2dup swap -  >r
    rot - 1+ >in +!
    r> here dup bl blank $!
    here ;
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_word
    jsr enter
    .word tor
    .word _tickstream
    .word under
    .word rfetch
    .word skip
    .word under
    .word rfrom
    .word scan
    .word drop
    .word twodup
    .word swap
    .word minus
    .word tor
    .word rot
    .word minus
    .word oneplus
    .word toin
    .word plusstore
    .word rfrom
    .word here
    .word dup
    .word bl
    .word _blank
    .word _dolstore
    .word here
    .word exit

```







!! WORDS&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|6SPACES]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7604&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;51&nbsp;[[>>|INFO]]


Display the entire dictionary.

~ display just the words in the current context
~ display words by vocabulary

```
: words
    cr >syms 2+
    begin
        dup nfalen ?terminal 0= and
    while
        dup id.  bl ?pause
        8 #out @ 7 and - spaces
        nfa+
    until drop ;

: words   ( -- )
     >syms 2+
 ( nfa )
     begin
         dup nfalen
 ( nfa flag )
     while
         dup id.
         nfa+
     until
     drop ;

: words   ( -- )
    cr >syms 2+
    begin
        dup nfalen ?terminal 0= and
    while
        dup
        name> >name.l10
        nfa+
    repeat
    drop ;
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_words
    jsr enter
    .word cr
    .word _tosyms
    .word twoplus
words01
    .word dup
    .word nfalen
    .word qterminal
    .word zeq
    .word andx
    .word qbranch
    .byt <(words02-*+1)
    .word dup
    .word _iddot
    .word _qpause
    .word eight
    .word numout
    .word fetch
    .word seven
    .word andx
    .word minus
    .word _spaces
    .word nfaplus
    .word branch
    .byt <(words01-*+1)
words02
    .word drop
    .word exit

```







!! //WRAP//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- addr )

[[<<|FLIPSCR]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$770e&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;7&nbsp;[[>>|PWRAP]]


Double variable, stores 25 bits of line wrap info for screen


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
wrap
    jsr docreate
    .word 0,0

```







!! //WRAP!//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( wrapd -- )

[[<<|?MKPKTS]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$16e8&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;27&nbsp;[[>>|SCR0]]



Updates the linewrap table at $E1-F8 to reflect the low 24 bits
in double `wrapd`.  Since line 0 ($E0) is never a continuation
line, (always $80) it is not written to.  Only 24 bits are
written to $E1-$F8, not 25.  Although unused, the most
significant (2^24) bit may be set, as a framing bit, used
to detect when the wrap double is full.



<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
wrapstore
    ;ldy #2
    jsr locals2
    stx z
    ldx #24
wrapstore01
    asl $e0,x
    lsr tos+1
    ror tos
    ror n+1
    ror n
    ror $e0,x
    dex
    bne wrapstore01
    ldx z
    jmp drop

```







!! //WRAP*//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( d1 d2 -- d )

[[<<|PASTE]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7721&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;54&nbsp;[[>>|WRAP+]]



Combines two linewrap tables into one.  It is expected that

* "d2" contains the top of the screen
* "d1" contains the remainder of the screen
* There are at least 25 "1" (40-column) and "10" (80-column) bits available



<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
wrapstar
    ;ldy #6                  ; TOS = D2H; N0 = D1L; N1 = D1H; N2 = D2L
    jsr locals6
    stx z
    lda tos+1
    bne wrapstar03              ; done already?
wrapstar01
    sec                         ; make sure we stop eventually
    ldy #4
    jsr wrapstar04
    bit n+3
    bpl wrapstar01              ; 0000 0000 0000 0000 0110 1011 1111   1111 1111 1111 1110 1111 0000 0000 0000
wrapstar02                      ; 0001 1111 1111 1101 1111 1010 1111
    clc
    ldy #6
    jsr wrapstar04
    rol tos
    rol tos+1
    beq wrapstar02
wrapstar03
    ldx z
    dex
    lda n+4
    sta stackl,x
    lda n+5
    sta stackh,x
    jmp next

wrapstar04
    ldx #0
wrapstar05
    rol n,x
    inx
    dey
    bne wrapstar05
    rts

```







!! WRAP^&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( logline -- d )

[[<<|BLKBUF]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$153b&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;47&nbsp;[[>>|RLENCODE]]



 Reads a portion of the linewrap table above the requested
 `logline`, up to but not including `logline`.

 Returns a right-aligned double with a copy of those high bit values

!!!pronounced: "wrap-above"


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
wrapabove
    stx z           ; preserve Forth data stack pointer
    ldx #0
    stx n+1
    stx n
    stx tos+1
    ldy tos         ; first physical line of this logical line
    stx tos
    tya
    beq wrapabove03
    sty n+2
    dex
wrapabove02
    inx
    cpx n+2         ; are we there yet?
    beq wrapabove03 ; leave if done
    lda $e0,x
    asl             ; nondestructively
    rol tos
    rol tos+1
    rol n
    rol n+1         ; append the next high bit to the double
    beq wrapabove02 ; this should always take the branch
wrapabove03
    lda n
    ldy n+1         ; high half of the double is going on the stack
    ldx z           ; restore Forth data stack pointer
    jmp pushya

```







!! //WRAP+//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( d columns -- d' flag )

[[<<|WRAP*]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7757&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;27&nbsp;[[>>|WRAPROLL]]


Append bits to the linewrap double `d` based on whether `columns`
is 40 or 80.  For 80, a '10' bit pair is appended,  and for 40 a
single '1' bit.  The return `flag` is zero if there are not yet 25
bits of linewrap in `d'`

!!!pronounced: "wrap-plus"


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
wrapplus
    sec                         ; always shift in a 1
wrapplus01
    ldy stackh,x                ; check msb 25.  full?
    bne wrapplus03
    rol stackl+1,x              ; shift in a single bit
    rol stackh+1,x
    rol stackl,x
    rol stackh,x
    lda #40
    cmp tos
    sta tos                     ; so we only do this once
    bcc wrapplus01              ; maybe shift in a 0 (if 80-column)
    ldy stackh,x
wrapplus03
    tya
    jmp put

```







!! //WRAPROLL//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( logline 40|80 -- )

[[<<|WRAP+]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7772&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;34&nbsp;[[>>|LINEINFO]]


Rolls the screen linewrap table up one or two lines


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
wraproll
    stx z
    lda stackl,x
    tax
    asl LDTB1,x
wraproll02
    cpx #24
    bcs wraproll03
    asl LDTB1+1,x
    ror LDTB1,x
    inx
    bne wraproll02
wraproll03
    sec
    ror LDTB1,x
    ldx z
    ;clc
    lda tos
    sbc #40
    sta tos
    bpl wraproll
    jmp twodrop

```







!! X)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|,Y]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7cdd&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;4&nbsp;[[>>|)Y]]

Indirect X addressing mode

```
asmindirx
    jsr _doasmmode
    .byt 5

```







!! //XLATE//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( char -- printablechar )

[[<<|4H.]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7549&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;15&nbsp;[[>>|DUMP]]





<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
xlate
    lda tos
    and #$7f
    cmp #$20
    bcs xlate01
    lda #'.'
    sta tos
xlate01
    jmp next

```







!! XOR&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( n1 n2 -- n1^n2 )

[[<<|OR]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0b50&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;13&nbsp;[[>>|NOT]]




<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
xor
    lda tos+1
    eor stackh,x
    tay
    lda tos
    eor stackl,x
    inx
    jmp put

```







!! //XT,//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( xt -- )

[[<<|PAGEALIGN]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$70a2&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;10&nbsp;[[>>|UNDEFINE]]


Encloses the execution token into the dictionary, paying heed
to page alignment and inserting the 'page' token into the
dictionary stream at page boundaries

```
: xt,   ( xt -- )
    $fc ?page  , ;
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
_xtcomma
    jsr enter
    .word pagemargin
    .byt $fd
    .word _comma
    .word exit

```







!! XYZZY&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- )

[[<<|MON]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$198d&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;3&nbsp;[[>>|CMDOFF]]


Forth breakpoint, used for debugging in VICE when `break .xyzzy`
is enabled, as it is in the `pettil.dbg` configuration file

usage:

```
: someword
   begin
       dup .
       1-
       dup bar 0=

       xyzzy    \ insert a breakpoint

    until drop ;
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
xyzzy
    jmp next        ; used as a VICE monitor breakpoint

```







!! //YANG16//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( nfa -- nfa )

[[<<|PASS1]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$6c07&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;49&nbsp;[[>>|PASS2]]


Conditionally copy the symbol at TOS to N0


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
yang16
    ldy #0
    lda (tos),y
    jsr inctos
    eor zi
    and #$f                     ; ~ unnecessary?
    bne yang16f                 ; same pearson hash?
    jsr nfalen01
    adc #0
    sta n+4
    beq yang16f
    jsr bloomhash01
    tax
    and #7
    tay
    txa
    lsr
    lsr
    lsr
    tax
    lda power2,y
    ora bloom+3,x
    sta bloom+3,x
    sec
    .byt $29                ; AND #
yang16f
    clc                     ; we did not copy
    rol R14H
    rts

```







!! //YIN16//&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( nfa -- nfa )

[[<<|AUTOMEM]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$6b7e&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;45&nbsp;[[>>|PASS1]]


Return -1 at end of list, -2 for copy, or a positive value to
skip this symbol.  Sweet16 carry flag is set if this symbol is
a clone.

|register|<|purpose|pass1|clone|h
|^R0|^ACC||^CFA||
|~|~|^return|^0 done with source||
|^R1|^TOS|nfa+|||
|^R2|^N0||^target|^target<br/>original|
|^R3|^N1|||original|
|^R4|^N2||positive|negative|
|^R5|^N3||||
|^R6|^N4||||
|^R7|^N5||||
|^R8|^N6|^symbol length|^length<br/>flags/length||
|^R9|^N7|newdp|^discard CFAs between<br>these addresses||
|^R10|^N8|tdict|~||
|^R11|^EXT|^return value|^<b>-1</b> end of list<br/><b>0</b> copy this symbol<br/><b>!0</b> do not copy<br/>||
|^R12|^SP||||
|^R13|^CPR||||
|^R14|^ST||<b>set</b> clone<br/><b>clear</b> not a clone<br/>||
|^R15|^PC||||


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
yin16
    jsr nfalen01
    stx R14L
    beq yin16d                  ; A=0? end of list. return -1
    eor zi
    bne yin16c                  ; bad length, return positive non-match
    bit n+4
    bpl yin16b                  ; match in pass1 mode
    lda n+13
    adc #0
    tay
yin16a
    lda (tos),y
    eor (n+2),y
    bne yin16d
    dey
    bne yin16a
    clc                         ; clone mode always returns carry false
    ror n+12                    ; clear sweet16 carry
yin16b
    lda #$c0
yin16c
    tay
yin16d
    dey
    sty 2*R11
    sty 2*R11+1
    asl n+12                    ; clone? is carry flag
    rol R14H
    rts

```







!! Z&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;( -- n )

[[<<|ASSEMBLER]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$7ad9&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;4&nbsp;[[>>|UP]]


!!!Assembler constant
zero page scratch location

```
ff cconstant z
```


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
asmz
    jsr docconst
    .byt $ff

```







!! //Zero page buffer and NEXT routine//

[[<<|BASIC bootstrap]]&nbsp;address:&nbsp;$0410&nbsp;&nbsp;size:&nbsp;588&nbsp;[[>>|User Area]]


This buffer holds an image at load time of zero page between
$00..$8D. PETTIL cold start calls the `zpswap` routine to
exchange it with the BASIC zero page on entry or exit.

Please note that `R12` is the Sweet-16 stack pointer, used by the
`BS` and `RS` opcodes.  It grows upward, and is initialized here to $0100
Changing this value will move Sweet-16's stack to somewhere else.
Any code that alters the value of `R12` will also move Sweet-16's stack
to a new area of memory, perhaps allowing Sweet-16 to overwrite
memory in unintended locations. Alter `R12` with care.

At $0086 is PETTIL's 15-clock inner interpreter consisting of
just three instructions.  Whoa.  It's fast.


<$button popup="$:/state/codeSlider">code</$button><$reveal type="nomatch" text="" default="" state="$:/state/codeSlider" animate="yes">

```
zpbuf
;==============================================================
;==== zero page buffer and user area                       ====
;==============================================================
;
;
;$00
;
    .word $0000,$1001,$2002,$3003   ; overlapping
    .word $4004,$5005,$6006,$7007   ; PETTIL registers
    .word $8008,$9009,$a00a,$b00b   ; and
    .word $0100,$d00d,$e00e,$f00f   ; Sweet16 registers
;$20
    .dsb bos,$aa                    ; low stack
;$50
    .dsb bos,$bb                    ; high stack
;$80
    .word 0, 0, uarea               ; zi, zlim, up
;
;       NEXT
;               +IP
;               [IP] -> PC
;
; Minimalist NEXT, gets copied to zero page
;
; PETTIL's NEXT and ENTER both put the responsibility for page
; alignment on the compiler, greatly improving code execution
; speed over a more conventional design at a cost of complicating
; things somewhat.
;
;$86
zpnext
    inc ip                  ; [5] (next)
    inc ip                  ; [5] (next1)
;ip = *+1
    jmp ($cafe)             ; [5] (nexto)

                            ;[15] cycles total
;$8D TIME                   ; end of zero page buffer, Jiffy clock is here

;==============================================================
; powers of 2 in a lookup table
power2
    .byt $80,$40,$20,$10,$08,$04,$02,$01

;==============================================================
;==== ALL SWEET16 OPERATION HANDLERS MUST BE ON SAME PAGE! ====
;==============================================================
    nop                         ; fine tune position of Sweet16

#if (* <> $04a6)
#echo PETTIL Build Error - Program counter is not at $04a6!
#echo You moved something, didn't you?  Sweet16 is expected
#echo to start at $04a6 (1190).  This is a problem.
#endif (sweet16 address check)
#echo .       program counter just before Sweet16 should be 1190, is:
#print *

#include "inc/sweet16.def"
#include "sweet16.a65"
;==============================================================
;==== ALL SWEET16 OPERATION HANDLERS MUST BE ON SAME PAGE! ====
;==============================================================


```
